title: Struggling to finish stories I start, any suggestions? - Quora

response.answer_text: First, understand that getting through the middle of the story is hard. Then, get comfortable with the idea of writing the boring stuff in order to get to the good stuff. Get comfortable with writing badly and fixing it in revisions. Stories don’t ‘read’ like well-written stories while you’re writing them. If you just want to read good stories, read the ones someone else has sweated over and reworked :) Next, think about why you’re becoming bored. Do you know your characters? Are they interesting to you? If not, do some deep-diving character analysis. We’re only going to care that they take that risk, if we know WHY it’s a risk to them, specifically. We need to know why it matters to them. Or perhaps you’re bored because you’re using storylines you’ve heard a million times before. Think about taking a trope (like, the bad guy killed the hero’s father) and turning it only its head (like, nope the bad guy IS the hero’s father). That can make for a much more psychologically complex and interesting story. Think about what annoys you in other people’s sci-fi and high fantasy stories. Why does no one ever use the bathroom? Why do wounds never become infected? Whatever it is, if it annoys you, write a scene where that happens. Another thing to consider is that you might be trying to write novels but calling them short stories. Short stories revolve around one incident, one moment, one big badaboom. You can’t have a lot of characters. You can’t tell a lot of backstory. You have to weave hints of the life-outside-this-incident into the story, but you can’t go off on a tangent, explaining the history of Hyr-Arund’l and its ten kingdoms…Choose your cultural references carefully and write the story of the people in the moment your story takes place. And always, always be thinking about conflict. This goes back to the ‘know your characters’ part. Conflict isn’t a big battle scene. Conflict is battling someone you love, or for something you care about in a very personal way. Keep writing!

Writing is hard work. I’m a published poet and write marketing materials for a living, but also struggle with keeping my novels going. A couple of thoughts. If you are stopped at a point in your story or novel because of boredom, perhaps your reader would also be bored. Objectively look at the plot and see how you might change it to add more action, more conflict, more surprises. Something has to happen. It is the main character’s challenges that make the story interesting. These obstacles to the protagonist’s goal(s) can be from the lead character himself/herself, (think Catcher in the Rye where Holden’s mourning over his brother’s death is preventing him from being successful at college); from life throwing crap at the character (think The Odyssey where Odysseus battles Posieden and mystical creatures in his 10-year journey to return to his wife Penelope); or from the antagonist—the person or people actively opposing the main character—(think Harry Potter and all those who tried to foil him: Lord Voldemort, Draco Malfoy, Gellert Grindelwald, etc.) And ultimately, you have to stick with it—keep working, keep writing, keep reading, keep learning about the craft. In a great TedTalks, Julian Griedmann says to velcro your butt in your chair and have your character take the “path of most residence.” Watch his talk called “The Mystery of Storytelling” and view other TedTalks on writing and creativity. Read books in your genre and take apart why they work or don’t work. Go to writer’s conferences. Read writer’s magazines and blogs. Continually learn about the art of writing There’s no magic formula. Hey, if I had all the answers I’d be a NY times best selling author! All I can tell you is that it takes tremendous dedication and effort to write a book. Writing my first historical novel took me years and was the hardest single project I’ve ever done. But I learned a lot and there’s a sense of satisfaction in actually completing a novel. (Even if I haven’t sold it yet.) So take a seat, take a fresh look at your story and imagine what could happen next.
